title: Jeremy Clarkson can't resist dig at Top Gear's Paddy McGuinness
text:
Jeremy couldn’t help but make the dig at the new Top Gear host (Picture: Rex)

Jeremy Clarkson can never resist a dig at his old show Top Gear – and Who Wants to Be A Millionaire literally delivered an opportunity on a platter in the new episode.

The TV presenter quizzed a potential millionaire quizzer on the history of the phrase ‘No Likey, No Lighty’ – which until his move to Top Gear, was Paddy McGuinness’s signature catchphrase from dating show, Take Me Out.

Hopeful Ross Arnett had got to the £1000 question when asked, and clearly was a fan as he managed to get the correct answer quickly.

After the win, Jeremy chucked on his shady glasses for the next question and casually asked: ‘What happened to the host of that…? Disappeared without a trace!’

Put your claws away, Jezza.

Now, for the uninitiated, Paddy McGuinness, alongside Freddy Flintoff, is the new presenter of Top Gear, the BBC show Jeremy presented with James May and Richard Hammond.

In 2015, after a row with a producer of the show, the BBC decided not to renew his contract, despite the popularity of the series.

After a rocky few years, Top Gear appears back on its feet (Picture: BBC)

In a sign of unity, Hammond and May left alongside him, and together they launched a rival driving show, The Grand Tour, on Amazon Prime Video.

The move proved to be a smash success, with long-held fans of the trio jumping ship onto the streaming service to keep up with their antics.

Over on Top Gear, the show has taken some serious hits in the four years that have followed, with Chris Evans proving to not be a hit with viewers and exiting after only one series, and Matt Le Blanc leaving the series at the end of 2018.

More: Jeremy Clarkson Piers Morgan mocks Greta Thunberg as she loses out on Nobel Peace Prize Inside The Grand Tour season 4: From exciting format revamp to near brushes with death How many episodes does The Grand Tour season 4 have?

However, Paddy and Freddy’s new combination seems to have worked, with their debut series at the beginning of this year gaining a resurgence of viewership for the show.

It’s getting its first Christmas special in four years later this year, with the gang heading to Asia.

Who Wants To Be A Millionaire continues Sunday at 8pm on ITV.
